author: By Clay Risen
title: Frank Fritz, a Host of the Antiques Show ‘American Pickers,’ Dies at 58
description: He and his friend Mike Wolfe launched the treasure-hunting show in 2010, part of a wave of reality TV aimed at finding fortune in everyday items.
content: Frank Fritz, a jocular Everyman who as one half of the duo behind the hit show “American Pickers” found ratings gold by unearthing fortunes in attics, basements and garage sales, died on Monday in Davenport, Iowa. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ella Leffland, Novelist Drawn to Portraying Outsiders, Dies at 92
description: Her work often drew from her upbringing in California amid World War II, such as her intricate novel about the Nazi leader Hermann Goering.
content: Ella Leffland, a California author whose critically acclaimed novels probed the layered history of her home state as well as the mental topography of outsiders and villains, including the Nazi leader Hermann Goering, died on Sept. 18 in San Leandro, Calif., in the San Francisco Bay Area. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Jay Pharoah’s White Gold Cross Necklace
description: The “Saturday Night Live” alum — whose new comedy special, “Jared,” was just released — wears a cross around his neck not just as a symbol, but a reminder of how to live his life.
content: Jay Pharoah has replaced his cross necklace a few times over the years. The cross his mother bought him warped after daily wear and tear; diamonds popped out of the one he bought himself from New York City’s diamond district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Conditions at Georgia Prisons Violate Constitution, Justice Dept. Says
description: At one facility, the body of an inmate, possibly strangled in his cell, was so decomposed that the coroner concluded he had been dead for two days without being discovered.
content: A Justice Department investigation into Georgia’s state prison system found conditions that violate the Constitution, including rampant violence, sexual assault, drug smuggling and gang activity, according to a report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. Destroyers Helped Israel Intercept Iran’s Missiles, Biden Says
description: The president said the United States was “fully, fully, fully supportive of Israel,” in a show of solidarity between two allies whose relations have become strained.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday afternoon that U.S. forces helped Israel shoot down waves of incoming missiles from an Iranian attack, rendering the assault “defeated and ineffective” in a show of solidarity between two allies whose relations have been deeply strained by the escalating conflicts in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Winston
title: This Port Strike Is the October Surprise Our Election Didn’t Need
description: It is long past time to fix the regulatory regime that created this mess.
content: This week we got a pre-election October surprise: a widespread strike that, depending on its duration, could lead to commodity shortages, higher prices and, ultimately, layoffs. It is landing at a time when voters are particularly upset about higher prices and in a cycle when the two major candidates are virtually tied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Scrambles to Contain Economic and Political Fallout of Port Strike
description: The labor dispute has forced President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris into a complicated position just weeks before the election.
content: President Biden urged the alliance representing port employers to present a fair offer to striking longshoremen on Tuesday as the White House scrambled to contain the economic and political fallout of the work stoppage at U.S. ports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: It’s Time to Make One-Pot Chicken and Rice
description: Put this schmaltzy, Mediterranean-ish recipe at the top of your fall cooking list.
content: The weather in New York last weekend offered a chilly, gray preview of the months to come. So at my house, we did the only rational thing: My husband lit a fire while I roasted a chicken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Michel and Vishakha Darbha
title: Eric Adams and the Creeping Threat of Foreign Interference
description: If other nations can influence New York City’s mayor, who can’t they influence?
content: Eric Adams, the mayor of New York City, was indicted last week for soliciting foreign funds for his campaign and for personal use. Casey Michel, director of the Combating Kleptocracy Program at the Human Rights Foundation, argues that to prevent the further degradation of our democracy, officials need to be more aggressive about enforcing existing foreign interference laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Is That a Panda? Or a Dog in Disguise?
description: Zoos around the world have occasionally used a little dye, or just brazenness, to pass off one animal as another.
content: You’re running a zoo. But visitors are clamoring for something different, more exotic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: What to Know About JD Vance and Project 2025
description: JD Vance has repeatedly tried to distance himself from the project, a conservative policy blueprint for a future Republican administration that has outraged Democrats.
content: Democrats have hammered former President Donald J. Trump and Senator JD Vance of Ohio, his running mate, over Project 2025, a conservative policy plan that pledges a radical transformation of the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The First Volleys of a Ballistic Missile War in the Mideast
description: And this one could involve the United States.
content: Update, 2:15 p.m.: As forecast below, Iran launched nearly 200 ballistic missiles at Israel beginning around 12:30 p.m. Eastern time. The Israeli antimissile system shot down almost all of them, Israeli sources said, and while there was some damage the attack was not considered particularly successful. There are no reports at this time of extensive casualties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Rivera
title: Shuffling Some Whimsy Into Poker and Blackjack
description: The familiarity of the 52-card deck has enabled video game designers to win over players with humor and randomness.
content: Few tools for killing time are as elegant or versatile as a deck of 52 playing cards, which for hundreds of years have provided a welcome excuse to gamble, puzzle, laugh or infuriate in idle moments. With the help of technology, video games are now finding delightful new ways to turn diamonds, clubs, hearts and spades into something stranger and even more charming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Do You Have Important Adults in Your Life Who Aren’t Your Parents?
description: A guest writer shares the joys of raising children who aren’t her own. What have your relationships with adults who aren’t your parents meant to you?
content: Do you have aunts, uncles, grandparents, godparents, family friends, coaches, teachers or other adults who aren’t your parents but have played an important role in your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Can Pro Sports and Drag Queens Coexist? A Mill Town Finds Out.
description: A gay couple embraced inclusion after buying an English rugby team. To their surprise, the fans bought in, too.
content: Kaue Garcia and Ryan O’Neill had owned a sports team for no more than six months when they decided the time was right to shake things up. What they needed more than anything else, they felt, was a drag queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: For East Coast Wine Importers, the Port Workers Strike Brings Fear and Uncertainty
description: The strike, disrupting shipments along the East and Gulf Coasts, comes as the wine industry tries to make up its sales after a downturn.
content: The longshoremen strike that closed ports on the East and Gulf Coasts on Tuesday has left wine importers scrambling to secure their European shipments ahead of the busy holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: New Children’s Museum of Manhattan to Open in 2028
description: Laurie M. Tisch has donated $50 million to the $300 million capital campaign for a new location on Central Park West.
content: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan on Tuesday announced that the philanthropist Laurie M. Tisch, its founding board chair, has donated a total of $50 million to the institution’s $300 million capital campaign for its new home at Central Park West and 96th Street, which is expected to open in 2028.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: After Warm Welcome in Asia, Pope Francis Gets a Fraught Reception in Belgium
description: Francis drew attacks over clergy sexual abuse, the role of women in the church and his stance on abortion, reflecting difficulties the church faces in the West.
content: Only days after he returned triumphant from a tour in the Asia-Pacific region where adoring crowds walked the jungle for days to see him, Pope Francis visited the European faithful in Belgium. The reception was more fraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Biden to Sign Bill Allowing Chip Projects to Skirt Key Environmental Review
description: The legislation, which would weaken federal environmental reviews for certain semiconductor manufacturing projects, has divided Democrats.
content: More than two years ago, President Biden signed a law that aimed to ramp up the nation’s production of semiconductors by offering generous subsidies and tax credits to companies. Since then, chip manufacturers have invested billions of dollars into new plants across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Weighs Retaliation After Iranian Missile Attack
description: Security analysts and former officials said the damage Israel had inflicted on Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed militia, had stripped Tehran of much of its deterrence against a wider Israeli attack.
content: Israel has a freer hand to respond forcefully to Iran’s missile barrage on Tuesday than it did in April, security analysts and former officials say, when its retaliation for the previous Iranian attack was a largely symbolic strike against an air-defense installation in Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Can a Vice-Presidential Debate Shift the Polls? History Shows It’s Unlikely.
description: But Tuesday’s debate could give voters a better sense of how they feel about JD Vance and Tim Walz, since many don’t have an impression of them.
content: A significant share of Americans have not formed opinions about Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota. That means Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate between the two men may help some voters develop a better sense of who they are, other than just the names of the running mates of former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Baby Hippo
description: Moo Deng, a baby pygmy hippo at a zoo in Thailand, has become a social media star. Are you a fan?
content: Have you seen or heard about the baby pygmy hippo at the Khao Kheow Open Zoo in Thailand who has been stealing hearts across the globe? Why do you think so many people are smitten with her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Chris Buckley
title: Song Binbin, Poster Woman for Mao’s Bloody Revolution, Dies at 77
description: She was said to have been involved in the first killing of an educator during the Cultural Revolution, drawing official praise. She later apologized for her actions.
content: Song Binbin, a student leader of China’s Red Guards who in 1966 was embroiled in the beating death of her high school principal, one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution — and who publicly apologized for her actions almost a half-century later — died on Sept. 16. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel Has Invaded Lebanon Three Times Before. Here’s a Closer Look.
description: In its earlier invasions, Israel said its aim was to secure its northern frontier and stop cross-border attacks, but it achieved less decisive results than military planners and political leaders intended.
content: Israel has invaded Lebanon three times before. On each occasion, it said its aim was to secure its northern frontier and stop militants from launching attacks across the border. And each time, the invasion had unforeseen consequences and achieved less decisive results than Israel’s military planners and political leaders anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Meet the Moderators: Margaret Brennan and Norah O’Donnell of CBS News
description: A pair of veteran news anchors will steer the vice-presidential matchup on Tuesday between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
content: CBS News, the network sponsoring Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate, is focused on providing a televised forum for voters to learn more about the candidates, Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Iran Attacked Israel With Waves of Missiles
description: Also, Tim Walz and JD Vance will face off tonight in a debate. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Iran fired roughly 180 ballistic missiles at Israel today, forcing millions of Israelis into bomb shelters and raising the likelihood of an all-out conflict between two of the most powerful militaries in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Judson Jones, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Lynsea Garrison, Mary Wilson, Luke Vander Ploeg, Alex Stern, Rob Szypko, Rikki Novetsky, Rachelle Bonja, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Alyssa Moxley
title: Hurricane Helene’s 600 Miles of Destruction
description: The storm swept through southern parts of the United States, carving a trail of lost lives and mangled homes.
content: Warning: This episode contains strong language and descriptions of death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Mexico’s First Female President Takes Office
description: A climate scientist and former mayor, Claudia Sheinbaum was inaugurated on Tuesday as the first woman to lead the country.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum took office on Tuesday, the first woman and Jewish person to lead Mexico in the country’s more than 200-year history as an independent nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: This Disease Can Damage the Liver for Years Without Being Detected
description: Four in 10 people are thought to have a potentially serious liver condition known as MASLD. Reversing it is possible if you catch it early.
content: Geraldine Frank was looking forward to celebrating her 62nd birthday when her son noticed some yellowing in her eyes. He wasn’t too concerned but wanted her to see a doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Bryant Park Grill Is Fighting to Survive
description: The restaurant, a big contributor to the revitalization of the Midtown park, may not get its lease renewed.
content: It’s Tuesday, and we’ll look at a lease renewal for a restaurant that has been a centerpiece of Bryant Park since the 1990s. We’ll also get details on why the city’s famously delicious tap water may taste different for a while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis, Aric Toler, Devon Lum and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Videos Show Iranian Missile Attack on Israel
description: While some missiles were intercepted by Israeli air defense, several hit locations in Israel, according to an analysis by The Times.
content: Videos from across Israel show dozens of missiles launched from Iran exploding on Tuesday evening, according to a New York Times analysis. The Israeli military said that Iran had fired about 180 missiles. While some were intercepted by Israeli air defense, several hit locations in Israel, the videos show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Olivia Nuzzi, Reporter Linked to R.F.K. Jr., Accuses Ex-Fiancé of Harassment
description: Her former fiancé, the Politico reporter Ryan Lizza, has vehemently denied the allegation, which she filed in a court complaint and to the F.B.I.
content: Olivia Nuzzi, the star political writer for New York magazine who was placed on leave after she disclosed her personal relationship with Robert F. Kennedy Jr., has accused her former fiancé of a campaign of harassment and blackmail, according to court filings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Arrests Woman Accused of Sharing Arms Export Data With China
description: The woman, who worked at an airport that is one of Europe’s largest cargo hubs, is accused of passing along “flights, freight and passengers” related to arms exports.
content: A 38-year-old Chinese woman living in Germany has been arrested on accusations of supplying China’s intelligence services with sensitive information on Germany’s weapons exports. It is the latest spying-related arrest amid increasing worry in Germany about intelligence gathering by China and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Veep Debate, or When the Opening Act Becomes the Headliner
description: Tonight’s showdown could be the last between representatives of both tickets before the election.
content: A funny thing happened during Aerosmith’s “Permanent Vacation” tour in the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa, Ken Bensinger and Eli Tan
title: Not Just Fun and Games: Politics Edges Deeper Into Livestreams
description: As more streamers discuss politics, including major events like Tuesday’s debate, they have become the focus of intense interest for both presidential campaigns.
content: During last month’s presidential debate, Hasan Piker appeared in the corner of the screen on his Twitch channel. With the debate playing live behind him, he interjected sporadically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: What Tim Walz’s Time in Minnesota Says About How He Governs
description: Mr. Walz was willing to move the state swiftly to the left as soon as Democrats had an opening. He supported all but one bill that fellow Democrats approved, issuing a single veto last year.
content: After Democrats won full control of Minnesota’s statehouse two years ago, they quickly pressed for change, enshrining a right to abortion under state law, legalizing recreational marijuana, requiring that employers provide paid medical and family leave, and funding free meals for most school students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Coates
title: Is a No-Nonsense Dutchman Just What NATO Needs?
description: In some countries, the job of a president or prime minister is a visionary one. Not here in the Netherlands.
content: Joseph Luns, who served as secretary general of NATO from 1971 to 1984, was not a typical diplomat. When he took charge of the military alliance after nearly 20 years as the foreign minister of the Netherlands, Mr. Luns surprised his new colleagues by leaving the office at 1 p.m. on Fridays and reportedly wearing bright red slippers at important summits because they were “more comfortable than shoes.” Asked once how many people worked at NATO, Mr. Luns is said to have replied: “About 50 percent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, Apple TV+ and More in October
description: “Citadel: Diana,” “Disclaimer,” “The Franchise,” “Star Trek: Lower Decks,” a Springsteen documentary and others arrive.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Sex Is Back on the Table in Paris
description: Balenciaga starts the heavy breathing. With shimmies from Hermès, Stella McCartney and Victoria Beckham.
content: Under the golden dome of Les Invalides, the 17th-century monument where Napoleon is entombed, and on the penultimate day of fashion month, Balenciaga built a giant black box — the better to house a 154-foot long (47-meter) wooden dining table, polished to a high sheen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 6 of ‘The Greatest’ Songs
description: Hear superlative tracks from Billie Eilish, Kenny Rogers and Alabama Shakes.
content: I’m going to keep things brief today, since I just got back from a whirlwind trip to lovely Quebec City, where I reported on the opening night of Billie Eilish’s world tour. I was curious to see how the 22-year-old Eilish would stage and perform the songs from her latest album, the sonically adventurous “Hit Me Hard and Soft” — especially those that require the oft-whispery-voiced singer to belt to the rafters. One of those songs has a lofty but familiar title: “The Greatest.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Inside a Trump Ad Slamming Harris Over the Push for Electric Vehicles
description: Scaremongering in Michigan, an ad claims that the vice president wants to “end all gas-powered cars” and that her policies would lead to “massive layoffs.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign is running this 30-second ad about jobs and the economy in seven television markets in Michigan, spending $952,462 so far, according to AdImpact. The ad denounces Vice President Kamala Harris on a key topic in a state where the auto industry is politically dominant: the rise of electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zaid Jilani
title: Why a Racist Professor Doesn’t Scare Me
description: Having grown up in an increasingly diverse America, I find Amy Wax’s resentments more pathetic than threatening.
content: I grew up in a corner of Cobb County, Ga., as the son of two Pakistani Muslims who came to the United States in the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman and Alison Bruzek
title: Thomas Friedman: ‘This Is Code Red Time in the Middle East’
description: The columnist weighs in on Iran’s retaliatory strike against Israel and what comes next.
content: Thomas Friedman, an Opinion columnist and Middle East correspondent, is keenly aware of the many red lines that have been crossed in the growing conflict between Israel, Iran and Hezbollah. He says, after Iran’s latest attack on Israel, anything is possible — from symbolic retaliation to the bombing of a nuclear facility. Hear why he believes that “this really is the most dangerous moment in the modern Middle East.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: Teenagers, What Makes You Want to Make Your Voice Heard?
description: This week, the Headway Election Challenge hears from teenagers who are turning out the vote for this year’s election, and even working to pass legislation.
content: Welcome to Week 4 of the Headway Election Challenge!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 1, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about the graft case involving Singapore’s former transport minister, S. Iswaran, misstated one of the charges that Mr. Iswaran faced. He was accused of accepting gifts as a public servant, not of accepting bribes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leo Robson
title: Karl Ove Knausgaard Reprises a Dark Tale, and Lays It On Thick
description: The third novel in the author’s Morning Star series considers how the extreme can engulf the everyday.
content: The latest multivolume project from the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard — author of the six-part novel “My Struggle” and a nonfiction quartet with a seasonal theme — is concerned with the inhabitants of an unnamed town during a recent August, when a new heavenly body appears in the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: 3 Children Injured, One Seriously, in Zurich Stabbing Attack
description: The police in Switzerland’s largest city said they had arrested a 23-year-old man after a midday stabbing attack.
content: Three boys were injured, one seriously, in a stabbing attack near a daycare center in Zurich on Tuesday, the local police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Andrew Tarlow Crosses the East River to Manhattan for Borgo
description: The menu for this trattoria stretches the boundaries of Italy’s boot.
content: A pair of spacious dining rooms, a working fireplace and a garden lured Andrew Tarlow, known for his Brooklyn restaurants, a bakery and other ventures, to settle his first Manhattan restaurant in what had been I Trulli. Its interior is lighter now, with paler wood finishes for a rustic but urban look. Mr. Tarlow and the executive chef, Jordan Frosolone, have created a menu for this trattoria that stretches the boundaries of Italy’s boot somewhat. They dress the chicory salad with Cabot Cheddar, and sneak sunchokes into the mushroom ravioli. But there are still chicken liver crostini, marinated artichokes with buffalo mozzarella, wood oven chicken with Marsala and fennel sausage with Umbrian lentils.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Anna Foley
title: Mark Cuban on Why He’s All In for Kamala Harris
description: One of the most surprising surrogates of 2024 argues that Harris is best for the economy — and therefore for everyone.
content: At one point, he supported the presidential aspirations of Donald Trump, a fellow reality TV star and businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Vance and Walz on the Campaign Trail
description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has acted as attack dog for the Harris campaign, and Senator JD Vance of Ohio has stepped in to explain away former President Donald J. Trump’s incendiary remarks.
content: In their efforts to supplement the candidates at the top of their tickets, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has played offense for the Harris campaign while Senator JD Vance of Ohio has sought to explain former President Donald J. Trump’s incendiary comments and criticized proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Halloween in New York: Things to Do in October
description: The Village Halloween Parade will feature a “cat lady” section, and the New York Botanical Garden has a Tim Burton light installation, plus much more.
content: Spooky season has arrived, and with it enough demented parties and darling pumpkins to fill a haunted mansion. Here’s a look at events to check out in the New York area through Halloween, no matter what your taste for the macabre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Dan Simmons
title: In a Pair of Disjointed Events, Trump Talks Gaza, Migrants and ‘Full Metal Jacket’
description: President Donald J. Trump criticized President Biden’s leadership and insisted again he would have prevented the crisis in the Middle East had he won in 2020.
content: Hours before the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday, former President Donald J. Trump traveled to Wisconsin and gave two rambling speeches laden with tangents, largely jettisoning any particular focus as he boasted about negotiating over the cost of a new Air Force One and lamented that a 1987 Vietnam War movie had not won an Academy Award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone and Alice Zoo
title: An Oasis in England’s Troubled, Polarized Opera Landscape
description: The Glyndebourne Festival, which receives little government support, has been mostly immune from recent convulsions of the opera industry in Britain.
content: The sun shone brightly over the downs of East Sussex on a summer afternoon while people trickled onto the grounds of Glyndebourne to hear an opera by Handel. Most of the men wore black tie, and many women were in floral gowns, as they picnicked among gardens and sculptures, and under the shadow of the property’s grand, Jacobethan manor house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Ghosts of Vice-Presidential Debates Past
description: The face-offs between the candidates on the bottom of the ticket have produced some standout moments. Here’s a look at the most memorable exchanges.
content: Here’s a test for anyone planning to watch the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday between JD Vance, the Republican senator from Ohio, and Tim Walz, the Democratic governor of Minnesota: Name a few memorable moments from vice-presidential debates over the past 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ash Wu
title: John Amos, a Star of ‘Good Times’ and ‘Roots,’ Is Dead at 84
description: He was the patriarch in one of the first sitcoms with an all-Black cast and an enslaved African in the American South in the blockbuster TV mini-series.
content: John Amos, who played a stern patriarch on “Good Times,” America’s first sitcom featuring a two-parent Black family, and who had a starring role in “Roots,” the slavery narrative that became America’s most watched show in the late 1970s, has died in Los Angeles. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: 3 Ambitious Song Cycles, but Only One Connects Mind and Heart
description: Todd Almond’s “I’m Almost There” is a work of wonder, while Gabriel Kahane’s “Book of Travelers” and “Magnificent Bird” are less effective.
content: Days and months, but also mere minutes, acquire outsize, perhaps even life-altering significance, in three song cycles currently playing intimate venues in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Is It Safe to Dermaplane My Face?
description: This peach fuzz removal technique is effective, experts say. But there can be downsides to trying it at home.
content: Q: I want to dermaplane my face to get rid of peach fuzz. But is it safe to do myself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: As Plant Sales Move Online, the Sill Closes Its Last Retail Store
description: A trendy company that embraced the plant craze of a decade ago has evolved to fill the needs of a changing demographic.
content: A decade ago, house plants were so popular among millennials that many would refer to themselves as plant moms or dads, devoting social media accounts to their plants and promoting it as a lifestyle. It was a time when trendy stores dedicated to plants made perfect sense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Rancher Gets 6 Months in Prison for Scheme to Create Giant Sheep Hybrid
description: Prosecutors said the Montanan illegally used tissue from a sheep from Central Asia and the testicles from a bighorn sheep to make large hybrids that he could sell at premium prices.
content: An 81-year-old Montana rancher was sentenced to six months in federal prison on Monday for running a nearly decade-long scheme in which he used parts from protected wildlife to create a giant hybrid species of wild sheep to sell at premium prices, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: How Trump Tore One Family Apart
description: His father was “an honest, loving man” but then fell under the sway of MAGA.
content: Last Tuesday evening in Midtown Manhattan, Jackson Reffitt, a 22-year-old from Texas, cried through the first professional play he’d ever seen, which was about him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: He Called 311 on the Police. They Called Back Making Dolphin Sounds.
description: Officer Brendan Sullivan was hit with a fine for harassing a Brooklyn resident who had complained about illegally parked police cruisers.
content: Officer Brendan Sullivan first used the breathy voice of a seductive woman. Then he panted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks, Ross Douthat, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Pamela Paul
title: ‘There’s a Trap Here’: Four Columnists Brace for the Vance-Walz Debate
description: With Harris and Trump locked in a tight race, will the vice-presidential debate do anything to help or hurt either ticket?
content: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists David Brooks, Ross Douthat, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Pamela Paul about Tuesday’s debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Pras Sues Lauryn Hill Over Canceled Fugees Tour, Alleging Fraud
description: Ms. Hill was accused of deceiving the other group members about tour finances. She called the lawsuit “baseless” and “full of false claims.”
content: After three years of stops and starts, a troubled reunion tour by the hip-hop trio the Fugees — Lauryn Hill, Wyclef Jean and Pras — was finally canceled in August, leaving fans wondering what had happened behind the scenes. One version of that story emerged in a lawsuit filed Tuesday by Pras against Ms. Hill and her company, MLH Touring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
title: Taylor Lorenz, Chronicler of Digital Culture, Will Start Own Newsletter
description: Ms. Lorenz is leaving The Washington Post, where she had a tumultuous tenure.
content: Taylor Lorenz, the high-profile tech columnist for The Washington Post, said on Tuesday that she was leaving the publication to start her own subscription newsletter on Substack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: As Crisis Builds, Lebanon’s Government Is Nowhere to Be Found
description: Already crippled by years of economic decline, political paralysis and other crises, Lebanon has little but its own citizens’ grit to survive the Israel-Hezbollah conflict.
content: Even for the Lebanese, it can be hard to say where it all went wrong for their tiny, beautiful country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Musical Comedy ‘Operation Mincemeat’ to Open on Broadway Next Spring
description: The show is about a real World War II episode in which British intelligence planted disinformation on a dead body to fool the Germans.
content: “Operation Mincemeat,” an improbably successful British musical comedy, already has a truth-is-stranger-than-fiction quality to it: It’s about a World War II military ruse in which British intelligence planted fake information on a dead body to (successfully) mislead the Germans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Robert Downey Jr. Is a Novelist With a Novel Muse in ‘McNeal’
description: The “Oppenheimer” star makes his Broadway debut in Ayad Akhtar’s timely new play about a literary lion who gets assistance from A.I.
content: The Vivian Beaumont Theater has, over the years, been memorably transformed into many specific, even exotic, locales: a Maine carousel, a Thai palace, a South Pacific Seabee base. But never has it looked more exotically nowhere than it does right now, as the setting for Ayad Akhtar’s “McNeal,” a thought experiment about art and A.I. With its softly rounded edges, cool colors and shifting screens, the sleek, vast space is as much an Apple store as a stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Eric Schmitt and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Launches Barrage of Ballistic Missiles at Israel in Retaliation for Assassinations
description: The 180 missiles fired at Israel on Tuesday evening sharply escalated the conflict between the two countries and threatened to engulf the Middle East in all-out war.
content: Iran fired waves of ballistic missiles at Israel on Tuesday evening, the Israeli military said, an attack that sharply escalated the conflict between Israel and Iran and threatened to engulf the Middle East in all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Adams Holds a News Conference, Alone and Without His Walkout Music
description: Mayor Eric Adams, now under federal indictment, turned his weekly news conference into a solo act, with no introductory music and no aides by his side.
content: Even before his weekly news conference began Tuesday morning, it was clear that the administration of Mayor Eric Adams had entered a less blustery era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Here Are the Finalists for the 2024 National Book Award
description: Percival Everett’s “James,” Salman Rushdie’s “Knife” and Diane Seuss’ “Modern Poetry” are among the honorees. Winners will be announced next month.
content: This year’s finalists for the National Book Award include the novel “James,” by Percival Everett, a retelling of the “Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” from the perspective of an enslaved man, “Knife,” by Salman Rushdie, a memoir about the stabbing attempt on his life and his recovery, as well as books translated from Arabic, Mandarin Chinese and French.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: When an Ohioan Debates a Minnesotan, the Midwest Takes Center Stage
description: JD Vance and Tim Walz each have roots in the Midwest, but how voters in the region will view the vice-presidential candidates’ different visions remains to be seen.
content: Senator JD Vance might invoke his childhood in a former steel town in southwest Ohio or talk about his time as a student at Ohio State University. Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota could drop anecdotes about his days as a football coach at Mankato West High School and his enthusiasm for mail-in rebates at Menards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Laborer From Gaza Is First Reported Fatality of Iran’s Missile Attack
description: Sameh al-Asali, who was sheltering in the city of Jericho in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, was killed when a large missile fragment slammed into him.
content: Sameh al-Asali was one of hundreds of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip sheltering in the city of Jericho in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, far from the war between Israel and Hamas back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Becoming Jack Nicholson
description: In his latest feat of prosthetic fun, the performance artist Alexis Stone transformed himself into the actor at the Balenciaga fashion show in Paris.
content: An hour before Balenciaga’s spring 2025 runway show in Paris on Monday night, Jack Nicholson walked out of the Scribe hotel in a white hotel bathrobe and slippers, gin and cigar in hand, and got into a white stretch limousine to head to the show. His sunglasses were on, his hair wild and askew, his unmistakable grin plastered across his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 15-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder in Fatal Shooting of Chicago Postal Worker
description: The authorities said that the teenager was found and arrested in Iowa on Monday. The police say he shot a postal worker on Chicago’s South Side several times in July.
content: A 15-year-old boy who the authorities said fatally shot a postal worker at close range in Chicago over the summer was arrested in Iowa on Monday and charged with murder, the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew A. Seligman
title: How JD Vance Disqualified Himself From Becoming Vice President
description: Why he represents a grave risk to the rule of law in American democracy.
content: On Tuesday night, JD Vance will face Tim Walz in what is likely to be the only vice-presidential debate of the 2024 election. As American voters assess Mr. Vance, they should scrutinize whether he has demonstrated the fundamental fidelity to the Constitution that the office requires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 479
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Megan Specia
title: Assange, in First Speech Since Release, Says He Was Jailed for Journalism
description: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, said in public remarks in Strasbourg, France, that his imprisonment had set a dangerous precedent.
content: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, told a rights group on Tuesday that his imprisonment had set a “dangerous precedent” for arresting journalists and criminalizing activities that were essential to the work of investigative journalists — his first public statement since being released from a British prison in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Donna Henes,‘Urban Shaman’ Who Heralded the Seasons, Dies at 79
description: Her solstice and equinox celebrations might involve an egg-balancing ritual and bonfires, all to remind modern New Yorkers of their humble place in the cosmos.
content: Donna Henes, who for half a century conducted rituals that honored the seasons and the stars — causing busy, materialistic New Yorkers to remember, if just for a moment, that they were all primates on an orb gently rotating in the cosmos — died in Ossining, N.Y., on Sept. 21, the eve of the fall equinox. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CBS Says Trump Will Not Participate in ‘60 Minutes’ Interview
description: This is not the first time that the former president has clashed with the country’s most popular television news program.
content: CBS News said on Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump had declined to participate in an interview with “60 Minutes” that would have been broadcast during a prime-time election special next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump’s Consistent Message Online and Onstage: Be Afraid
description: Donald Trump has long used fear as a tool to stir up his conservative base. He’s taking his doomsday approach to a new extreme, predicting World War III and other catastrophes.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump swings wildly from topic to topic at his rallies, veering from tariffs to immigration policy to the problems with electric vehicles. But he tends to return to the same apocalyptic message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: In a Shattered Ukrainian Town, a Long Battle Nears a Sudden End
description: The loss of Vuhledar, at the intersection of two fronts, would complicate the defense of a regional transit hub and strengthen Russian supply lines, Ukrainian soldiers say.
content: For nearly three years, the mining town of Vuhledar has underpinned Ukraine’s defense of its southern Donbas region, the industrial heart of the country that has become a tableau of desolation and destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: France’s Prime Minister Urges a Divided Parliament to Give Him a Chance
description: Michel Barnier vowed to slash spending and temporarily raise some taxes, but his plan must contend with three bitterly opposed political blocs and an aversion in France to working across party lines.
content: In his first appearance before France’s fractured lower house of Parliament, Prime Minister Michel Barnier pleaded on Tuesday with lawmakers to work with his government on tackling the country’s most pressing issues, first and foremost a looming budget crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,201
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Iran’s Tepid Response (So Far)
description: We explore why Tehran has responded so meekly to recent attacks on its top officials and close allies.
content: It has become a mystery in the current Middle East conflict: Why has Iran responded so meekly to recent attacks on its top officials and close allies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom Tacks to the Middle With California in the Spotlight
description: While Donald J. Trump has attacked California as too liberal for the nation, Gov. Gavin Newsom has vetoed several bills that could have become political fodder.
content: For much of the past year, conservatives have considered Gov. Gavin Newsom of California a perfect symbol of liberal excess, a well-coifed coastal governor with national aspirations whose state seemed to embrace undocumented immigrants while homeless encampments proliferated on the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Amy Qin
title: Tim Walz Said He Was in Hong Kong in 1989 During Tiananmen. Not True.
description: Mr. Walz taught at a high school in China as part of a program sending American teachers abroad, but he did not actually travel to the country until August 1989.
content: Repeatedly over the years, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has said that the year he spent teaching in China began with a trip to Hong Kong during the pro-democracy protests in the spring of 1989 that culminated in the deadly crackdown that June in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eve Sampson
title: As Iran Launches Attack, Israel’s Next Move May Determine Course of War
description: A look back to an exchange of strikes in April suggests one possibility for what could unfold over the coming days.
content: In recent days, American officials have been assessing how a missile exchange between Iran and Israel could unfold. The most optimistic prediction has been a repeat of what happened in April, when the United States, Israel, Jordan and others intercepted almost all of the hundreds of missiles and drones fired toward Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: Iran Launched Ballistic Missiles at Israel
description: Plus, Jimmy Carter turned 100.
content: Iran fired several waves of ballistic missiles at Israel, a sudden assault that left Israel fighting simultaneously on three fronts. The attack was a sharp escalation in the long-simmering conflict between Israel and Iran, and raises the likelihood of an all-out war between two of the most powerful militaries in the Middle East. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: In Iran, Military Commanders Win Debate, and Israel Is Hit
description: The barrage of missile fire came after much debate among Iranian leaders, officials there say.
content: After days of sharp debate at the top levels of government, Iran’s senior military commanders prevailed, and almost 200 ballistic missiles were sent speeding toward the heart of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Katie Glueck and Michael C. Bender
title: What to Watch For in Tuesday’s Vance-Walz Debate
description: As the two running mates hold their first debate in New York, here is what to be on the lookout for.
content: Follow live updates on the vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: ‘Climate Havens’ Don’t Exist
description: The worst damage from Hurricane Helene came in areas that were expected to be relatively immune to the effects of climate change.
content: Hurricane Helene has torn through cities across the Southeast, killing at least 120 people in six states since it made landfall on Thursday. The death toll is still expected to rise. Some of the worst damage has happened inland in North Carolina, and almost a third of those killed were in Buncombe County, which surrounds Asheville, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Behind School Bus Mess, a 45-Year-Old Contract That’s Hard to Change
description: Students across New York City are waiting up to an hour for school buses, as a driver shortage and conflict over a contract hamstring the city’s ability to find a solution.
content: Less than a month into the school year, Dawn Akerley has developed a very particular morning routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Pachelli
title: Looking to Meet Your Neighbors? Get on the Tennis Courts.
description: A different way to understand your community — and yourself.
content: In 2021, I moved from Harlem to leafy Fort Greene, Brooklyn. I’m a longtime competitive tennis player, and one of my first outings in the neighborhood was to an annual community tennis tournament in the park that a friend recommended. Eager to scout the competition and cultivate a tennis tribe in my new home, I walked up the hill and watched rallies across the six courts. I noticed one guy in bright orange shorts with rapid footwork and a slight limp. I turned to the stranger watching next to me and asked what the guy’s deal was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: What Are Ballistic Missiles?
description: A look at the kind of weapons fired into Israel.
content: Iran unleashed waves of ballistic missiles on Israel on Tuesday, a shift from the drones and cruise missiles it used in its April attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Another Way Jimmy Carter, 100 Today, Bested His Fellow Presidents
description: The longest-lived president has also written more best-selling books than any modern president — and had the fewest written about him.
content: Jimmy Carter, who turned 100 today and is the longest-lived U.S. president in history, holds another, less noticed distinction: He’s the most prolific author of any president in a century. Mr. Carter has written or co-written 32 books in his lifetime, 20 of which became New York Times best sellers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Eurozone Inflation Slows to 1.8%, Bolstering Bets on Faster Rate Cuts
description: Investors now expect the European Central Bank to lower interest rates at its next meeting in October.
content: Inflation in the eurozone dropped below the European Central Bank’s target in September for the first time in more than three years, paving the way for faster interest rate cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Water for Elephants’ to Close on Broadway
description: The musical, based on the best-selling novel, featured dazzling acrobatics and puppetry. Its final performance will be Dec. 8.
content: “Water for Elephants,” a circus romance adapted from Sara Gruen’s best-selling novel, will close on Broadway on Dec. 8, the latest big-budget musical to shutter during a challenging time for the theater business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Their Design Work Dried Up, So They Built an Inventive Home for Themselves
description: During the early pandemic, two architects found most of their jobs on hold. It was time to get creative.
content: For years, Eric Bunge and Mimi Hoang thought about building a vacation house. But the couple, who live in Brooklyn and run an award-winning firm called nArchitects, never seemed to have the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: A Fancy New Restaurant in London, Staffed by the Recently Homeless
description: In London’s upmarket Primrose Hill, a Michelin-starred chef is employing people on the edge of homelessness as chefs, wait staff and cocktail makers.
content: It’s been three weeks since the restaurant, Home Kitchen, opened its doors and Mimi Mohamed is pretty sure she knows the lemon tart recipe by heart. But just in case, a small notebook where she has carefully written out the ingredients is propped up at the back of the steel counter: 18 lemons; 420 grams of butter; 900 grams of sugar; 24 eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Slams Trump’s Idea to Adapt ‘The Purge’
description: “Good news: He stopped talking about Hannibal Lecter,” Jimmy Fallon said. “Bad news: He suggested we do ‘The Purge’ instead.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: At 75, Charles Atlas Is Coming of Age as an Artist
description: “About Time,” a retrospective opening in Boston, comes at a time of radical change for a pioneer of media dance.
content: Charles Atlas dyes his sideburns carrot-orange and has the slender physique of a club kid. He lives in the mess of a loft-ish little apartment near the Meatpacking District in Manhattan. He spends his time looking at screens and playing with what he sees there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Insults Harris’s Mental Fitness, Adding to Questions About His Own
description: Readers condemn the former president’s attacks and cite examples of his  incoherence and unfitness. Also: Jimmy Carter at 100; Christian women; the Oakland A’s.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: abdicate
description: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word abdicate has appeared 23 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 22 in The New York Times Magazine article “The Heavy Toll of Desertion From the Russian Army” by Sarah A. Topol:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Raises New Concerns Over Chinese Lending Practices
description: A Treasury official will call for greater transparency over emergency currency “swap” loans to struggling countries by China’s central bank.
content: The United States is raising new concerns about China’s practice of making emergency loans to debt-ridden countries, warning that a lack of transparency surrounding such financing can mask the fiscal predicaments facing fragile economies that have turned to China for help.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Fire Renewed Forests. Now It’s Their Enemy.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 1, 2024.
content: “It looks like the trees melted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Sun Narin
title: Cambodia Arrests Journalist Known for Exposing Scam Centers
description: The charge of incitement came after the United States punished a tycoon for what it said was his role in the scam compounds.
content: The authorities in Cambodia brought an incitement charge on Tuesday against a journalist known for his work on exposing human trafficking in online scam compounds, less than a month after the United States punished a powerful Cambodian businessman over what it said was his role in the criminal enterprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Why Restoring Power After Helene Is Complicated
description: Damage went beyond downed power lines. Hundreds of substations went out after the storm. Getting them back online is difficult.
content: Hurricane Helene didn’t just knock down power lines across the Southeast — it also flooded many electrical substations, which can take weeks or months to repair if they are severely damaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: Israel Has Destroyed Half of Hezbollah’s Arsenal, U.S. and Israeli Officials Say
description: The Lebanese militia is seeking more weapons from Iran, the officials said. It has yet to fire large barrages at Israel, and its top ranks have been crippled by Israeli strikes.
content: Israel’s recent airstrikes in Lebanon destroyed about half of the missiles and rockets that Hezbollah had accumulated over more than three decades, dealing a blow to the militia’s capabilities, according to senior Israeli and American officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Alan Rappeport
title: Ohio Reaps Benefits From a Climate Law JD Vance Repeatedly Attacks
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has called for clawing back unspent funds included in the Inflation Reduction Act, President Biden’s landmark climate bill. That could have adverse impacts in Ohio.
content: President Biden’s key climate law has long drawn the ire of former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Greshko
title: Wreck of ‘Ghost Ship of the Pacific’ Found Off California
description: The rediscovery of the vessel, which was captured by the Japanese for a time during World War II, highlights the potential of underwater autonomous vehicles to map the ocean floor.
content: On Aug. 1, a ship dropped its unusual cargo into a patch of ocean some 70 miles northwest of San Francisco: three orange robots, each more than 20 feet long and shaped like a torpedo. For a day, the aquatic drones autonomously prowled the waters, scanning nearly 50 square miles of ocean floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Where the Dockworkers’ Union and Port Operators Stand on Key Issues
description: The union representing thousands of striking dockworkers is pushing for bigger wage increases than port operators have offered, and a ban on automation.
content: A standoff between port operators and the union representing East and Gulf Coast dockworkers, fueled by disagreements over wages and the use of automation, culminated in a strike on Tuesday, with tens of thousands of workers walking off the job after midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: A 64-Year-Old Literary Agent and TikTok Star Adds ‘Novelist’ to Her Résumé
description: Betsy Lerner has spent decades in the publishing industry. Writing her first novel, “Shred Sisters,” unlocked a completely new side to her creativity.
content: The opening of Betsy Lerner’s debut novel, “Shred Sisters,” is literally explosive: The adolescent narrator’s glamorous older sister has crashed into their living room window, and is covered in glass shards and blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: School Bus Blaze in Thailand Kills at Least 23
description: The vehicle was returning from a field trip and caught fire outside Bangkok. Rescuers were still searching for bodies in the wreckage.
content: A bus filled with schoolchildren and teachers caught fire just outside Bangkok, the capital of Thailand, on Tuesday, killing at least 23 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Dana Rubinstein
title: Adams Confidant Steps Down Amid Federal Corruption Investigations
description: Few people in city government were closer to Mayor Eric Adams than Timothy Pearson, who had a role in handling migrant shelter contracts.
content: One of Mayor Eric Adams’s closest aides and confidants resigned on Monday, less than a week after the mayor was indicted on corruption charges — and nearly a month after federal agents seized the aide’s phones in a separate corruption inquiry, according to a resignation letter his lawyer said had been sent to the mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Ken Page, Who Starred in ‘Cats’ and Voiced Oogie Boogie, Dies
description: The Broadway actor had a storied career that spanned decades.
content: Ken Page, the Broadway actor whose extensive career included standout roles in “The Wiz” and “Cats,” but whose rich baritone voice reached a wider audience as Oogie Boogie in the perennial hit movie “The Nightmare Before Christmas,” died on Monday at his home in St. Louis. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Somers
title: Cannabis Has Become Upscale Chic. I Miss the Old Red-Eyed Stoners.
description: Widespread legalization has created a polished new market for cannabis products — one that’s trendy, spalike and weirdly unfun.
content: Last summer, in an effort to cut down my drinking after a particularly boozy vacation, I bought a case of cannabis soda online. The soda — called Lo Boy, by the brand Cann — was blood-orange-and-cardamom flavored; each can contained one milligram of THC and 15 milligrams of CBD. I’d drink one in lieu of a glass of wine while cooking dinner. On an empty stomach, it would give me the mildest feeling of euphoria — the equivalent of, say, a half a glass of wine — which faded after about 10 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clémence Michallon
title: If You Liked the Plot in ‘The Plot,’ Then You’ll Love Its Sequel, ‘The Sequel’
description: Jean Hanff Korelitz follows her hit thriller with the related tale of a novelist hounded by anonymous threats. But this writer aggressively aims to turn the page.
content: In 2021, Jean Hanff Korelitz’s novel “The Plot” earned exactly the kind of acclaim the characters in her book — aspiring writers — yearned for: It became a best seller, was hailed as “insanely readable” by Stephen King and is being adapted into a limited series starring Mahershala Ali.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Sends Troops Into Lebanon
description: Plus, creating fashion in prison.
content: The Israeli military announced early this morning that it had begun a “limited” invasion of southern Lebanon. The military said it was targeting Hezbollah infrastructure in villages close to the border that “pose an immediate threat” to communities in northern Israel, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Breast Cancer Continues to Rise Among Younger Women, Study Finds
description: Death rates are declining among U.S. women with breast cancer. But the disease is turning up more often in women under age 50.
content: Rates of breast cancer — the second leading cause of cancer deaths in U.S. women — climbed by 1 percent a year from 2012 to 2021, and even more sharply among women under age 50 and among Asian American/Pacific Islander women of all ages, according to an American Cancer Society report published on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Why Did Israel Send Troops Into Lebanon?
description: Israel says it aims to cripple Hezbollah’s forces in an area of southern Lebanon that the armed group controls.
content: Israel and Hezbollah have fought wars before, most recently in 2006, a monthlong conflict that ended with a United Nations cease-fire resolution calling on both sides to retreat from a 20-mile buffer zone in southern Lebanon along Israel’s northern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump Thinks Harris’s Sisterhood Is a ‘Sorority Party.’ He Should Think Again.
description: The vice president is an institutionalist politician. Her membership in a “Divine Nine” organization helps explain why.
content: A few weeks ago during the presidential debate, Donald Trump chided Kamala Harris for not attending Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to a joint meeting of Congress in July because, Trump said, “She was at a sorority party of hers. She wanted to go to the sorority party.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Mapping Israel’s Invasion of Lebanon
description: While details of the operation are scarce, Israel has ordered residents of many southern towns to move north.
content: Israeli forces crossed into southern Lebanon late Monday in an operation aimed at Hezbollah forces and infrastructure in the rugged border region. Israel ordered people in more than two dozen towns to move north of the Awali River, which is more than 15 miles from the Israeli border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: The Busiest Port on the East Coast Comes to a Stop
description: The strike by longshoremen has halted commerce at Newark and other ports on the East and Gulf Coasts, affecting an ecosystem of supply-chain workers.
content: Every workday, on his early-morning drive to his job overseeing a warehouse in northern New Jersey, Sean Murphy takes in the frenetic scene of the busiest port on the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chanel Parks
title: All the Makeup Brushes You Actually Need — and How to Clean Them
description: From a hard-working powder brush to a simple spoolie, these are the tools the professionals recommend.
content: “The biggest misconception about brushes is that you need a hundred of them,” says the makeup artist Diane Kendal, who’s also the creative director of Rabanne Beauty. “Unless you’re a pro, it’s better to have only a handful and wash them regularly.” The New York-based makeup artist Linda Gradin estimates that most people need just three to seven brushes for everyday use — to even out the skin, add some color to the cheeks and create simple, well-defined eye looks. The best ones can also do double duty; you can apply lipstick with a small, angled eyeliner brush, for example. And while putting on makeup with your fingers can be great — skin-to-skin contact warms formulas, helping them to blend easily — you need brushes if you’re looking for polish and precision. Here’s a breakdown of the essential styles to have on hand, and how to clean them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu and Yan Zhuang
title: Typhoon Krathon Nears Taiwan After Lashing the Philippines
description: The storm is expected to bring torrential rain this week to Taiwan’s south, including Kaohsiung, the island’s third-largest city.
content: Typhoon Krathon was barreling toward Taiwan’s populous southwest on Tuesday with powerful winds and heavy rain, forcing the authorities to ground some domestic flights and close schools and offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Layoffs, Mergers and Ego Clashes, Oh My! How One Reporter Covers It All.
description: To report on the business of media, the journalist Ben Mullin says he is “endlessly curious” about the people populating his own industry.
content: When Ben Mullin was a junior at California State University, Chico, he spent most of his time in the tiny basement of a 40-year-old building, working as an editor on the student newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: At Least 6 Killed and Several Injured in Tel Aviv Shooting
description: The authorities described the shooting, which took place on a light rail train, as a terrorist attack by two Palestinian gunmen. No group immediately claimed responsibility.
content: Two Palestinian gunmen opened fire Tuesday on a light rail train in Tel Aviv, killing six people and injuring at least 12 others, the Israeli police and emergency services said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: How the Dockworkers’ Strike Could Ripple Through the Economy
description: Transportation and warehousing sectors are poised to first feel the pinch, with a broader economic fallout expected if the strike drags on.
content: As dockworkers at East and Gulf Coast ports walk off the job, economists are bracing for the strike to reverberate across the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolás Medina Mora
title: When a National Hero of Mexico Was a Nobody in New Orleans
description: Yuri Herrera’s novel “Season of the Swamp” portrays the antebellum South through the eyes of a humbled leader in exile.
content: Among the tragic heroes and comic villains who fill the pantheon of Mexican history, few command more solemn respect than Benito Juárez, who in the mid-19th century rose from destitute origins to become his country’s first Indigenous president. His place in the national imagination is not unlike the one a Black Abraham Lincoln might have occupied in America: a secular saint who overcame racist barriers to bring justice and reform to the motherland. His canonization may well be warranted, but as it happens with most victims of hagiography, it’s hard to think of Juárez without yawning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Patrick Kingsley, Peter Eavis, Kellen Browning, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Israel Starts Lebanon Ground Invasion, and Hundreds Are Missing After Helene
description: Plus, Jimmy Carter turns 100.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Adams Accuses Prosecutors of Leaking Investigation Details to News Media
description: In a court filing Tuesday morning, lawyers for Mayor Eric Adams asked a judge to hold a hearing about what they said were grand jury secrecy violations.
content: Lawyers for Mayor Eric Adams accused federal prosecutors of leaking information about the investigation that led to the mayor’s indictment last week, and asked the judge presiding over the case to hold a hearing and issue sanctions, according to a Tuesday morning court filing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Rescuers Push Through Helene Debris to Find People and Restore Power
description: Blocked roads and bad cellphone service in remote mountain towns have made it hard to find people who are still unaccounted for after the storm.
content: Rescuers fanned out across the mountains of southern Appalachia on Tuesday, scouring the region for missing people and rushing supplies to communities still in dire need of food, water and power after Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Camhi
title: The Love Affair Annie Ernaux Captured in Words and on Film
description: In 2003 the Nobel laureate had a torrid romance with Marc Marie, a French acquaintance. In “The Use of Photography,” they deliver a vivid chronicle of their relationship in photos and essays.
content: Men have repeatedly lectured me about Annie Ernaux. “You must read ‘The Years,’” a date once told me, responding to the homage I’d written, staying up all night in a Swiss hotel room, upon learning that this writer whose work I’d admired for decades had been awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature. (In the piece, I mentioned that “The Years” lay unopened on my bedside table at home.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: 5 Halloween Film Festivals Worth Traveling For
description: It’s October, and horror movie festivals scratch both the weekend getaway and scare-the-bejesus-out-of-you itch. A guide to some worth checking out.
content: Watching weird indie horror movies at home on Tubi can be a bunch of fun. So can going to the local multiplex to see the latest scary Hollywood blockbuster with other shrieking fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Port Workers Strike on East and Gulf Coasts
description: Members of the International Longshoremen’s Association walked out for the first time since 1977 in a standoff over wages, benefits and job security.
content: For the first time in nearly 50 years, longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts went on strike Tuesday, a move that will cut off most trade through some of the busiest U.S. ports and could send a chill through the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Vance Pitches Republican Megadonors on Eve of Debate
description: Senator JD Vance addressed some of the party’s biggest donors at a private sit-down before the American Opportunity Alliance.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio took a break from debate preparation on Monday evening to make a direct pitch to the Republican Party’s billionaire class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: How Chicken Tenders Conquered America
description: The breaded, fried tenderloin turns 50 this year. Yes, there was a time before it was sold in every cafeteria and airport.
content: Fifty years ago, the breaded, fried chicken tender as we know it was invented in Manchester, N.H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Could Republicans Gain a Senate Seat After the Menendez Scandal?
description: Curtis Bashaw, a hotel owner, is competing to represent New Jersey in the U.S. Senate against Andy Kim, a Democratic congressman.
content: Curtis Bashaw maneuvers his lanky body through a maze of picnic tables, stopping every few steps to repeat his upbeat introductory pitch to voters waiting for lunch on a recent weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: MacArthur Foundation Announces 2024 ‘Genius’ Grant Winners
description: On Tuesday, 22 anonymously nominated Americans were recognized with fellowships and an $800,000 stipend.
content: While the groundbreaking Indigenous teen comedy-drama “Reservation Dogs” may not have taken home any Emmys this year, the show’s co-creator Sterlin Harjo has been awarded a different prestigious prize: a MacArthur Fellowship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in October
description: Keri Russell is back and so is Ali Wong. Here’s a roundup of what’s worth checking out for U.S. subscribers this month.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Alicia Keys, LaChanze and Kristin Chenoweth Gather to Support Black Theater
description: The stage stars were among more than 600 people who turned out for an evening of dinner and performances to benefit Black Theater United.
content: LaChanze was in the mood to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: SoftBank’s Masa Son Nears His Next Big Bet: OpenAI
description: The Japanese tech billionaire is poised to back the start-up, as part of his pledge to go on offense when it comes to investing in artificial intelligence.
content: SoftBank’s outspoken founder and C.E.O., Masa Son, has long talked about wanting to become a giant in artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Metropolitan Opera’s Season Begins With a Boom
description: “Grounded,” the new work that opened the season, has been joined by revivals of three Puccini, Verdi and Offenbach classics.
content: The Metropolitan Opera’s season began not with a bang or a whimper, but with a boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: The Thrifty Ingredient That Made Weeknight Cooking So Much Easier
description: The humble lentil is a quick-cooking kitchen powerhouse.
content: With dried lentils in your pantry, you can quickly add a little tenderness to meals. They’re inexpensive, quick to cook, good for the environment — and for you. But even if lentils weren’t such a virtuous legume, they’re good to have around because their gentle flavor and creamy texture add body to many meals, from soups and dals to salads and pastas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Chiaverina
title: Why the Pre-eminent Artists of Internet Culture Escaped to Rural Ohio
description: A visit to Ryan Trecartin and Lizzie Fitch’s compound in the sticks.
content: RYAN TRECARTIN WAS, for a time, one of the most ubiquitous and influential artists of his generation. He seemed to arrive fully formed at age 23 with the 2004 short film “A Family Finds Entertainment,” his senior thesis project at the Rhode Island School of Design. It follows a naïve but troubled character named Skippy as he struggles to escape the stranglehold of domesticity, gets hit by a car, and then is somehow conjured back from the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Lebanon, Batman, Baby Hippo
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

description: The attack, which comes days after the assassination of Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, marks a sharp escalation in the conflict between Israel and Iran.

title: Family Survives Hurricane but Is Left With Just One Suitcase
description: Hurricane Helene left Aaron Smith, his wife, two sons and dog with nothing but a single suitcase. They are some of the many victims state and federal crews are working to aid after the storm devastated southern Appalachia.
content: Hurricane Helene left Aaron Smith, his wife, two sons and dog with nothing but a single suitcase. They are some of the many victims state and federal crews are working to aid after the storm devastated southern Appalachia.

content: Brandon Davis returned to his business in Asheville, N.C. for the first time since Hurricane Helene devastated the area several days ago.

description: Gunmen opened fire on a light rail train in the Jaffa neighborhood of Tel Aviv, killing at least six people and injuring several others.

title: Why Georgia’s Election Board Is Being Sued
description: Georgia, one of the most important battleground states in the country, finds itself back in the news after Democrats sued the Georgia State Election Board on Monday.
content: Georgia, one of the most important battleground states in the country, finds itself back in the news after Democrats sued the Georgia State Election Board on Monday.
